abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome for the Primary Health Care
            Project for Tajikistan was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project: This was,
            for all intents and purposes, a Learning and Innovation Loan
            and should have been recorded as such. Institutional reform
            in countries like Tajikistan is not easy. Extensive
            supervision by the Bank should be anticipated and planned
            for countries with weak institutional capacity. Partnerships
            on substance can be risky. Sharing facilities and staff
            across multiple Projects is not easy in practice.

5084723.trustfund:
TF037293-TAJIKSTAN - HEALTH AND
            EDUCATION PROJECTS,TF027773-TAJIKISTAN PRIMARY HEALTH CARE PROJECT,TF030314-DANISH CTF GENERAL FY03 - (ALL
            EXCEPT SUB-SAHARAN AFRICA),TF021818-TAJIKISTAN HEALTH PROJECT,TF038774-ARMENIA - SUPERVISION OF
            PRIMARY HEALTH CARE PROJECTS,TF037823-ECA REGION - HEALTH,TF025595-PHRD - HEALTH LEARNING &
            INNOVATION LOAN

abstracts.cdata!:
The Primary Health Care Project in
            Tajikistan, will test a model of health care delivery, based
            on primary care, and per capita resource allocation, to
            improve service delivery, and quality of health care. Within
            the strategic context, the project will enhance critical
            social services, assist vulnerable groups, and build
            institutional capacity. There are four components. 1)
            Training will be provided under the primary health care
            development component, supporting health care services
            delivery. It includes activities in physician retraining
            programs; development of specific disease management
            protocols and treatment guidelines; production of teaching
            materials; development of a national health sector human
            resources training plan; ensuring standards for family
            health centers, compatible between training and facility
            upgrading components; and, medical personnel retraining. 2)
            The health facilities rationalization, and development
            component, will ensure implementation of health systems
            plans in two regions, in consultation with local
            administrations, service providers, and stakeholders. 3) The
            health care financing system, will develop a methodology for
            population-based funding at the regional level, to be tested
            only in pilot regions. 4) Management and institutional
            capacity within the Ministry of Health, and, administrations
            in pilot regions/hospitals, will be strengthened.
